abstract: If "Seven Minutes in Heaven" only conjures up over-analyzed middle-school disappointments, you're in luck. (If it conjures up middle-school conquests, you're in denial.)
snippet: If "Seven Minutes in Heaven" only conjures up over-analyzed middle-school disappointments, you're in luck. (If it conjures up middle-school conquests, you're in denial.)
lead_paragraph: If "Seven Minutes in Heaven" only conjures up over-analyzed middle-school disappointments, you're in luck. (If it conjures up middle-school conquests, you're in denial.) Mike O'Brien, a writer for "Saturday Night Live," has redefined the sophomoric game for a grown-up, but possibly still sophomoric, audience. The rules are still the same: two people, one closet, roughly seven minutes. (The timing isn't precise, but it never really was.) There are also a few additions: cameras, which at least at the suburban basement parties I attended were not part of the deal, and celebrities.
